ost_step.1: Let x represent the number of items each person receives when distributed equally among three people who received different amounts previously due to one receiving double that another got minus five.
ost_step.2: Therefore, if two get y each before equal distribution, then both receive (y/3) plus ((x+5)/3), resulting in them having exactly half again than their original count together.

direct_answer.text: First define variables: let `x` represent the additional items someone gets beyond twice the others', making initially `(y+(x+5))` items for those individuals collectively. We want these counts halved post distribution (`((y*(2)+x*2)-5)/2`), equalling our new divided item count per person—a third of this sum since we distribute across six ('tripled'). Hence, derive equation expressing initial difference times two diminished even further upon sharing out amongst triplets: `\[(\frac{(y+2)(x+5)}{6}) - (\frac{2}{3}*\frac{xy}{3})\]`. Reducing yields simplistic algebra leading us right up against the known quantity; zero denotes no excess past equality achieved through tripling shares versus pair division within said group subset comprising four participants.
